title: Retrieval and alteration of exposed media on Android Oreo

profile.name: Nextcloud
profile.about: Access, share and protect your files, calendars, contacts, communication & more at home and in your enterprise.

vulnerability_information:
Good afternoon.

Any media downloaded from the cloud server within the Android app is subject to third party modification and server re-upload without explicit  user consent.

This happens at least on Android Oreo, as data is automatically stored on shared folder /sdcard/Android/media/com.nextcloud.client/nextcloud/ACCOUNT/.

This report could be probably divided in two as one aspect is data confidentially while the other one is data integrity, which could be solved separately.

## Impact

Local media availability  is impacted if device is not web connected as third app can delete any downloaded assets

Local media confidentiality is impacted as any third app can access any downloaded assets, even if  Nextcloud lock is set up.

Local media confidentiality is impacted as any third app can alter any downloaded assets, even if  Nextcloud lock is set up. Once the user open up NC app, content get automatically reuploaded to sever.

As it seems NEW content does not get uploaded nor DELETED content get removed, it seems that Nextcloud app maintain a local sync setup and this setup could be used for metadata control to at least prevent/control data re-upload.

if Nextcloud lock is setup, it would also good to at least provide a minimal confidentiality setup so that data gets encrypted PER default and decrpyted on tmp folder only on click (which is required to open assets with PDF/other app).

activities.message:
Hi,

this behaviour is intended, so that you can .e.g. play your downloaded music with another app like VLC.
You can select a different storage path in app's settings to prevent other apps from accessing the data.

Login protection is to prevent people from doing unwanted things on the server in your behalf.

This therefore works as intended and is no bug.

Best regards,
Tobias

activities.message:
Hi.

Okay I may understand this for the read capability. Thought it should be clearly stated that "make available offline" implies, per default, that any other app can read.

But how then to consider the fact that any 3rd app are able to simply rewrite them to empty file is an intended feature ? Unless we have a desync backup of the cloud storage, it means that I put a  media offline on Android phone,  it can be simply lost forever by a simple file rewrite from a 3rd app?


I am referring to 
" Local media confidentiality is impacted as any third app can alter any downloaded assets, even if Nextcloud lock is set up. Once the user open up NC app, content get automatically reuploaded to sever."
which should have been written 
"Media *integrity* is impacted as any third app can alter any downloaded assets, even if Nextcloud lock is set up. Once the user open up NC app, content get automatically reuploaded to sever."

I should also add that the "play your downloaded music with another app like VLC." does not hold as per default if you open the media through NC app, you can trigger a "Open with" even if private storage is used.

It seems to me that, at minimum, there is a default setup to use external drive that is insecure and made only for storage optimization, isn't it?

activities.message:
Hi there.

As it seems that this report will stay closed, please let me allow to ask for public disclosure.

I strongly believe that NC app should by default use a secure storage. Most of the user do not understand the impact of data storage choices and expect it to be secure by default.  Not to mention that changing the storage is not that obvious for non tech friendly users (and non Android security aware).

However, default settings allow any app installed on the user device, with external storage privileges, to
1. retrieve user pub/private keys for push
2. get data
3. alter data
4. delete data by putting them to empty file

Even if lock is set up on NC app, opening the app will just resync the data, even if the lock is not disabled. A malicous app can just simply alter data and open NC app with an Intent to force sync and data loss.

Hello,

sorry for the delay.
I will sit next week together with our Security Engineer, to see what we can do in this case.

You say that you can retrieve use pup/private keys for push: can you clarify this? 
I tested it with latest version and the folder where the keys are stored is: /data/user/0/com.nextcloud.client/files/nextcloud/nc-keypair

Ref: https://github.com/nextcloud/android/blob/69b86b5e6c63e2e4cfe4663344cd8cb427fd0243/src/gplay/java/com/owncloud/android/utils/PushUtils.java#L110-L111

activities.message:
Hi Tobias.

Thanks for getting back to me.

# A) default settings
I understand your position regarding data disclosure if the user decided to do so. However, I believe that by default data shall NOT be publicly available. This would be also a first mitigation against point B.2 stated below.

# B) preventing data loss
## 1. lock
 NC app should not sync if lock is set up. This goes against the  lock features, doesn't it? At least for data integrity protection through the upload to server

## 2. data modification 
Preventing undesired app to trigger data loss is just vital for users that uses Nextcloud sever as a primary storage. I know  companies that use Nextcloud (based on my recommendations :D) but because of these issues, I would not recommend them to install Android app unless I give clear setup instructions and review these with them (e.g. access to shared contact only and sync with Davdroid).
 
Note that regarding this "storage on public folder", I could here refine the issue in 2 points:
* 2.1 data explicitly saved locally on public folder.
* 2.2 data NON explicitly saved locally but just opened 

For 2.1, unless stated that choosing /sdcard folder allows other apps to (read and) alter NC server of locally saved content, NC app should ask user confirmation before syncing back to server 

for 2.2, shouldn't NC use a private folder as here we are more talking of a cache feature than a real storage one? Data opened in NC becomes basically readable by any apps. As storage on private folder works very well on NC app, I believe that 2.2 case should be handled within private folder and through FileProvider "framework" (as you have for private storage file management).

# C) Regarding nc keypairs
 I see app was updated on store on December 23, 2018. So probably the keys are a leftover as the app was installed before. I fail to reproduce current issue on the latest version too and will try again on the other device I was reproducing the issue.

activities.message:
Hi Julien,

While I understand your concerns. Nextcloud is a file sync and share solution. If other apps can't access the data at all there is very little use in setting up the android app to begin with. Regarding the overwriting of files. Nextcloud has versioning by default. And as always regular backups of your server are important. For example the same attacks hold true if you are on the desktop client.

Regarding 1. This was not what the lock feature was designed for originally. The original idea was that users could not modify server config. Initiate shares etc. But I'll discuss with Tobias what we think falls under this. Because I do not feel a lot for asking 20 random files that are edited since the last tie if they should be uploaded. Then disabling syncing when the lock is enabled makes most sense.

About asking the user to sync back (2.1). I do not think this is a workable solution. A lot of our background jobs are controled by the Android OS. So the app might come at a completely different time asking you if you want to sync back file x/y/z.txt. In which case the user might have already forgotten in. Here it might be possible to maye show a 1 time warning the first time you enable syncing?

What might be a possible enhancement that when a user sets up the lock that they are also asked if they want to move their files to protected storage. that would not kill all the usability of the app by default while still giving people that want to lock their account a bit more control.

I'll discuss some of this with Tobias over a beer and we'll get back to you.

Cheers,
--Roeland
